msDesc.head:
Letter from
John Gibson Lockhart
to Maria Edgeworth, , May 15 1847 National Library of Scotland stamp on first and last pages of letter

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, including non-standard spelling, line breaks, and hyphenation of words. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p:
I said I
wd would tell you the upshot of my
endeavours to arrange the
worldly business I had to
grapple with in Scotland. It
comes to this. I found that
the Colonel had entailed
not the house library &
immediate grounds alone
(as I had supposed) but the
whole land at Abbotsford
on his brother & then on
my son &c but that there
remained a debt of £8500

I carried on these liens in his father's
time of trouble & 24000 £ more of
old bookselling debt - besides
an odd £1000 of claims against
the founder - with all which I
must deal as my father in
law's sole surviving executor
The only funds were the remaining
copyrights of his works - Now
much diminished & every
3 months diminishing in
number. Cadell offered, as
he had done sometime ago to
the Colonel, to obliterate the
8500 £ & the 2400 £, on
receiving the remaining share
of the copyrights

in Scotts Works & in my Life of
him and to take an abridged
Edition of the Life in payment
of the other £1000 - and being
wholly at a loss how to meet
demands for interest ( at this
Whitsuntide even) & really
believing that no one else cd could
or wd would offer so much for what
I had to dispose of - I have
signed the agreement above
indicated . Abbotsford
therefore is free as respects the
debts of the founder & so far
at all events a great object
of my ambition is accomplished.
Whether my boy is to receive

any income from his sacrifice will
depend on the state of his uncle's
own matters which cannot be
ascertained till we hear
from agents in Madras. Lady
Scott however does not think
he has left any debts but
what we already know of
& if that be so I believe his
personal estate will about
clear them off. should that
turn out to be the case, the
present rental of the Estate
after defraying the jointure
& other necessary charges
comes to some £400 per
annum

It is possible & I think even
probable in railway times
that the woods may by &
large begin to yield more
than hitherto - as yet they
have barely paid the
foresters - and it might
also be possible to let the
house - but this I shd
greatly dislike as the late
Sir Walter did & for
the same reasons which
are feelingly indicated in the
earnest injunctions of his
will as well as his entail
(both 1839 put before he
left England) as

to keeping every article as long as
possible in the state and
position in which his father
bequeathed them to him.
The entail requires my son to
add the name & arms of
Scott to his own & this will
be done at the convenience
of the Heralds' college of
course.

Lady Scott will have a tolerable
income now & a much
larger one if she outlives
her mother. Her plans are
as yet quite unfixed - but

I much doubt if she will live
at Abbotsford (which wd
would
be the most desirable thing
for my son) or even in
Scotland. Her mother, in anti
-cipation anticipation of their return, had
taken Huntly house, to be
near them - you remember
the house above Chiefswood
where the Fergusons used
to be - Both it & my little
glen are just where they
were only the woods on the
skirts of the Eildrens so grown
that I cd could hardly see the
summits from my garden.
Lady Scott continued wonderfuly wonderfully

tranquil - & Sir Adam is quite
paternal in his treatment of
her - in short she is as well
& as well placed as one
cd could wish her to be for the
present. My york has
required his corps at
Canter
-bury Canterbury
& missy & I have
resumed our usual
quiet habits here
div.closer:
ever yours affectly affectionately
J G Lockhart
